review_blob: Bottle at La Birreria in Manhattan. Pours a deep golden with a fizzy and fluffy white head that never completely dissipates. Fantastic aroma of sweet grapefruit rind with just a touch of pine and just a hint of grass. Flavor is light and crisp as expected with citrus and piney hops with a touch of biscuit malt background. Light bodied.. complex and flavorful as well as refreshing.

On tap at the Birreria in manhattan. Poured a lively effervescent golden with a fluffy white head. Floral and sweet aroma with notes of honey and wildflowers and Belgian spicing. Flavor follows with a touch of sweetness leading to a crisp dry finish. Light fizzy body, appropriate. Refreshing and complex.

On tap at The Foundry in Sandy Hook. Poured mahogany with a thin off white head. Light pleasant nutty, somewhat dry aroma with a touch of caramel. Taste is lightly sweet up front, burnt caramel, some dry smokiness. Finishes dry with a bit of a metallic nuttiness. Surprisingly complex and drinkable.

Poured a voluptuously effervescent golden with a huge fluffy white head. Aroma of light spicy grass and cinnamon with a touch of pine. Flavor is highly complex yet light, with notes of spiciness and herbal hops, yet leaning more towards the sweet side of the balance. Very little alcohol flavor shows through. Body is light and fluffy and evanescent. Overall a very nice saison... refreshing and complex.

On tap at Citi Field.  Poured dark amber with a fizzy white head. Aroma of slightly sweet biscuity malt with a slight touch of piney grassy hops. Flavor is lightly sweet with a nutty toffee character and a clean slightly hoppy finish. Not bursting with complexity but refreshing and drinkable.

Had at the Carpenters Arms in Windsor, England. Poured amber with a small white head. Soft, understated aroma of light sweet malt and a bit of toffee with almost no hop presence. Flavor follows; sweet, a bit of fruit and toffee, almost no hop bitterness to it. Body felt somewhat cloying and undercarbonated. Little flavor, not very refreshing, cloying body. Not impressed.

Bottle shared at Johns gathering. Poured a dark amber with an off-white head. Had not idea this was going to be a black IPA, a style I am admittedly not terribly keen on. Aroma of some wildflowers, a bit of pine, and biscuity malt. Flavor is bitter with a buttery biscuity beginning (hurray for alliteration), some bitter pine and grapefruit rind, leading to a surprisingly sweet though somewhat metallic ashen finish. Hops dont seem dominant enough for this to be a true double and the few off flavors are hurting my enjoyment of this. Eh.
beer_name: Moab Brewery Desert Select Black Imperial IPA

review_blob: Bottle shared at Johns gathering. Poured a mahogany with a light tan head. Aroma is sweet dark fruits mixed with some roasty coffee. Flavor is surprisingly acidic following the aroma (though not so much considering the addition of cranberries) with some flavors of light chocolate acidic fruit dominating. Overall some nice flavors but I was not really crazy for the acidity clashing from the sweeter roastier flavors that would otherwise have comprised the the bulk of the flavor profile if it had not been for the cranberries.

On tap at Max Downtown in Hartford. Poured a dark amber/mahogany with a fizzy off-white head. Light aroma of some pine hoppiness and some sweet malt. Flavor is dry with piney hops and a touch of caramel sweetness. Somewhat one-dimensional but inoffensive.

Served cold. Poured clear. Light aroma of some apple, a bit of honey, perhaps a touch of alcohol. Flavor follows and is surprisingly sweet with notes of honey and wildflowers, some dark fruits, coconut, with perhaps a touch of alcohol coming in. Pretty smooth. Overall a nice sake, though not as subtle as the finest, and has a clean sweet flavor and goes down easily.

Poured an effervescent amber with a fizzy/frothy off-white head. Aroma is hoppy with notes of pine and a bit of citrus with a touch of toffee underneath. Flavor comes through predominantly as piney hops with a touch of malt sweetness... bitter, clean, refreshing. A tasty brew that I thought was an APA... I guess I have a bit of a taste for amped-up ambers.
beer_name: Rogue Captain Sigs Deadliest Ale (Northwestern Ale)

review_blob: Poured black with a dark brown head. Rich strong aroma of roasty malts and dark fruits, an interplay of bitter and sweet. Flavor is surprisingly sweet though not intensely alcoholic as I expected... with strong notes of chocolate, vanilla, and dark fruits with a slight roasty hop kick. More drinkable than I initially gave it credit for, and a nice imperial stout overall.

Poured an effervescent dark amber with a fizzy/frothy off-white head. Decent aroma of some pine and citrus hops with a touch of earthy bitterness. Flavor is quite good with notes of sweet toffee and strong pine hops... earthy bitterness with little metallic flavor. I didnt know this was a DIPA, although that would certainly explain the dark color and richer body, though the hop profile did not strike me as being that prominent. Still, a good drink.

Poured an effervescent dark mahogany with a fizzy light tan head. Somewhat sweet aroma of dark fruit with a touch of smoky molasses... bock-like, but not as rich as some of the style standouts. Flavor is nice and complex with notes of smoky molasses and bitter coffee with vinous fruits hanging in the background. The coffee made its presence known without becoming overpowering. A rare case when a beers taste stands out as its strongest attribute.
beer_name: Ithaca Excelsior! Kaffinator Double Espresso Bock

review_blob: On tap at the Ginger Man in Norwalk. Poured a hazy amber with a fizzy/frohty white head. Some aroma of bubble gum and toffee, a bit of ashen earthiness. Flavor is rather dry and heavy on belgian yeast esters with strong notes of coriander, dark fruit, and of course, ginger. The ginger makes this very dry, perhaps a bit too much so. Toffee takes dominance in the finish, overshadowing the spices. Somewhat unrefined and although drinkable far from memorable.

On tap at The Old Mail Coach in Conwy, Wales. Only nitro tap Ive enjoyed in the UK.  Poured amber with a creamy off-white head. Decent aroma of some light citrus and a bit of toffee... typically light but nice. Flavor is refreshing with notes of citrusy orange and grapefruit rind with a bit of butter toffee. Body is nitro watery but almost tasteful. Im glad I found this is in the veritable no mans land of Wales.

Poured an effervescent amber with a tall creamy/frothy off-white head. Aroma of some pine and lemony citrus with a touch of toffee. Flavor follows with predominant pine and lemon citrus, a bit of alcoholic earthiness, and a soap and toffee finish.Fairly decent, but I would have liked some different citrus flavors in my IPA.

Poured a clear effervescent amber with a fizzy/frothy white head.  The aroma is rich and inviting with notes of grapefruit and orange with some notes of sticky candy and undertones of refreshing pine. Flavor is refreshingly bitter with notes of orange peel and some ruby red grapefruit with some fresh pine. Some sweetness is in there as well. Not as heavy as I expected it to be... a nice body but just the refreshing flavors I wanted from this. Surprisingly complex yet light and drinkable. I enjoyed this.

Bottle shared at Cletuss Chinese New Years Party... thanks John!  Poured a thick black with a fluffy dark brown head.  Sweet aroma of dark chocolate with a touch of fruit, alcohol, and a little hop bitterness.  Taste is quite dry with lots of bitter chocolate notes and some coffee with a hop kick to the finish.  Alcohol is well-hidden.  Given the chocolate labeling, I pegged this beer as being sweeter than it turned out to be.  As we tried this one alongside Darkness, I couldnt help but think that I would have liked to try a mix of the two, as both had qualities in a stout I enjoy but neither exactly stood out for me as spectacular.

beer_brewer_name: Port Brewing Co / The Lost Abbey
review_blob: UPDATED: FEB 22, 2009

Generously shared by Cletus at his Chinese New Years celebration... thanks John! Poured a thick velvet onyx with a tall dark brown fluffy head. Rich aroma of sweet and bitter chocolate, some vinous fruits, some candy sugar, and a touch of citrus hops. Flavor is fairly sweet with predominantly dark fruit notes, with lots of dark cherry and molasses with perhaps some honey wheat bread lingering in the background.   The finish leads to notes of bitter citrus rind and pine hops, somewhat balancing the sweetness and adding some dryness to the beer. Body is quite soft... neither cloying nor thick. The dark fruit in this almost gives it a barley wine feel, which surprised me. Well crafted for sure, though maybe not the type of imperial stout I am inclined to enjoy most.

Poured a clear effervescent amber with a fizzy/frothy white head.  Aroma of grapefruit and orange, some pine, some soap, a slight touch of candy sweetness.  Flavor is quite bitter with strong notes of grapefruit rind, earthy and bitter pine, a slight touch of soapiness, leading to a very dry bitter finish.  No metallic tinge to the bitterness, which is nice.  Overall a very bitter IPA witih sufficient complexity and almost no sweetness which maintains a pleasant refreshing character.  A major notch in the column of those who do not care for sweet or more balanced   IPAs.

On tap at The Spot in Bethel. Poured a murky amber with fizzy white head. Aroma of thick and cloyingly sweet raspberry pure with alcohol notes and a touch of brown sugar. Flavor is first of harshly metallic and ashen alcohol, like chewing on an ashtray, followed by a shockingly artificial tasting raspberry jam flavor. Hurts to swallow. A disgusting alcoholic mess with no artisansl qualities whatsoever. DFH should have scrapped this one, I think.

Poured orange and cloudy with a fizzy/frohty off-white head.  Strong aroma of citrus pine and earth.  Flavor follows, sharply bitter grapefruit rind, lots of dry alcohol, some earthniess.  Feels simply like a decent yet non-memorable double IPA, though I do enjoy the FFF signature citrus hops.
beer_name: Three Floyds Fantabulous Resplendence (X Anniversary Ale)

review_blob: Poured amber with a fizzy off-white head.  Aroma of some refreshing pine and grapefruit, bit of toffee, nothing exceptional.  Flavor follows with bitter earthy pine, some light citrus, a bit of alcohol.  Flavor and body feel underwhelming.  Would have been a decent regular IPA, not a good double.

Poured a clear lightly bubbly golden with a small fizzy white head.  Crisp aroma of sweet toffee, grassy and spicy saaz hops with a touch of ginger and lemon.  Flavor follows and is rather dry with notes of ginger spiciness and some fresh pine and grassy hops.  8.6% alcohol hardly present.  Body feels somewhat flat for what should be a lively effervescent drink.  Balanced and pretty refined.  Nice to see Stones take on the hoppy Belgian, and though not perfect, is quite good.
beer_name: Stone 20th Anniversary Encore Series: 08.08.08 Vertical Epic Ale

review_blob: Poured brown with ruby highlites and a fairly tall fizzy brown head that dissipated quickly.  Aroma of some light vinous fruits, some dark chocolate, a bit of roastiness, somewhat restrained.  Taste is lightly sweet with notes of dark fruits and some light roasty character.  Some watered down coffee in the flavor.  Body feels a little thin.  Not sure if Ive held on to it too long, but it feels a bit skeletal.  Perhaps Im expecting too much from a schwarzbier.

Poured an orangeish amber with a fizzy/frothy off-white head.  Nice citiric and bitter pine aroma with some alcohol and a mild touch of sweetness.  Flavor is citrus and piney hops with some earthy and metalic bitterness to the alcohol character, like sucking on a coin.  Luckily that only shows towards the end of the finish and the entire preceding mouthful is enjoyable.  This beer has the nice characteristics of Unearthly that I enjoyed, but also the ashen alcoholic bitterness of Hoppe which I did not.  In the end is not superior to Unearthly in my opinion.

Poured a cloudy amber with a tall fizzy/frothy white head.  When cold, faint aroma of some light toffee and floral spiciness.  As it warms, aroma develops notes of sweet candy sugar and some citrusy hops.  Flavor is nice and complex, with bitter pine and grapefruit hop notes mixing with sweet toffee and some light ginger spiciness.  Although there are several examples of hoppy belgian strongs, this is more of a Belgian take on an American double IPA, with lots of candy sweetness balancing citrusy hoppiness.  The Belgian yeast esters work to make it a unique and refreshing beer.  Nice.

Bottle 3313, Sept 2007.  Poured a thick black with a creamy light brown head.  Light aroma of caramel, toffee, coffee, some faint tobaccoish whiskey notes.  Flavor is soft but complex with notes of oak, scotch, roasted chocolate, and tobacco, leading to a bitter finish.  Alcohol well hidden.  Started out full and complex but got more watery through the glass... not completely sure why.

Poured a dark black with a fizzy/frothy brown head.  Faint aroma of some dark fruits, some tobacco, and some roasty chocolate.  Flavor follows but feels more complex than the aroma, with some bitter roasted chocolate, some dark coffee, some sweet pipe tobacco, with a dry finish that is only mildly alocholic.  Touch of acidity in the fruit flavor.  Not sure if thats an intended flavor or due to the years Ive held on to this in my cellar.

Generously shared by John from a growler.  Poured a murky mahogany with a fizzy/frothy white head.  Sweet aroma of honey wheat bread and some fruits.  Flavor is a nice mix of sweet and dry with notes of maple syrup, fresh honey, a bit of wheat bread, leading to a contrasting hoppy and dry finish.  Very flavorful and complex, in contrast to other one-dimensional examples we had experienced previously.

Poured a cloudy dark mahogany with a large fizzy/frothy off-white head.  Aroma of lemon peel, horse-blanket, cinnamon, and some caramel.  Flavor is very complex, with some tart and dry notes starting first mixing with some sweet roasty caramel and a bit of toffee, with a touch of cinnamon spiciness.  Touch of lemony citrus in there too.  Not a single scrap of the 8% alcohol is present in the taste.  A unique surprise.  Bottle calls it an Abbey Dubbel, but doesnt seem to fall into any particular classification.  Very good.

Growler shared generously by John M.  Poured a clear mahogany with a small white head.  Rich aroma of tannic red wine, some barnhouse funk, some sweet grapes.  Flavor is balanced and complex with strong sweet and sour notes, red wine, and some strong fruit essences, leading to a semi-dry finish.  Really delicate yet rich in flavor, dangerously drinkable, straight-forward yet funky at the same time.  A triumph.

Poured a cloudy amber with a tall fizzy/frothy off-white head.  Rich and sweet aroma of cherries, cinnamon, fresh lemon juice, a bit of oakiness.  Flavor follows and has the acidity expected, though not the sweetness.  Tart and woody cherries mix with olive pit and a touch of cinnamon and coriander, leading to a dry and slightly bitter finish.  A bit of sweetness could have been used to round this out a bit more.  Body is somewhat light and fizzy though it works with the oaky acidity of the beer.  Although the flavor is somewhat less enticing the aroma, it is still complex, refined, and refreshing.  Overall I found this to be a very good beer.

Poured an effervescent amber with a fizzy off-white head.  Aroma of some faint grapefruit and lemon citrus with some grassy hops thrown in.  Taste is lightly sweet toffee with some notes of grassy hops and some earthy pine bitterness, with just a touch of alcoholic character to round it out.  Easy drinking amber ale, though I would have liked it to be a bit more assertive... atlhough I know thats not the point of an amber.  Oh well.

Poured a hazy effervescent amber with a tall fizzy/frothy white head.  Aroma is sweet and spicy with notes of peach and pear, cinnamon, a bit of alcohol, some floral notes.  Flavor is somewhat sweet with some notes of cinnamon and nutmeg spiciness and some apple and pear, a bit of bourbony oak, leading to a semi-dry finish.  Well-made as usual for Allagash, but didnt blow me away with originality.

Growler generously shared by Cletus.  Notes on this one are thin... slightly sweet, though not as much as I thought it would be, with just a hint of oaky nuttiness.  Decent, though I thought they would make it a tad sweeter to emphasize the flavoring.

Poured an effervescent golden with huge bubbles with a massive creamy/frothy off-white head which, strangely enough, never dissipated.  I am at a lost to explain this.  I have had heads that have very slowly dissipated, but this one never seemed to move at all.  Aroma of floral citrus and pine, though a tad faint to me.  Flavor is fairly sweet, living up to this beers claim of being balanced.  Heavy orange and grapefruit citrus with a touch of pine makes for a pleasant hop profile, leading to a semi-dry finish.  Body feels a little thick.  A good IPA with no noticeable flaws and some unique characteristics that did not blow me away but did leave me satisfied.

Poured a clear reddish amber with a very tall and frothy off-white head.  Aroma of butter toffee, wheat bread, some earth and pine.  Flavor is quite dry and bitter with notes of earthy pine needles, dry butter toffee and a bit of dishwater soapiness.  Finishes with a slightly ashen dryness. Body feels somewhat light.  Decently made, with a respectable hop character, though not very drinkable on its own.

Poured a clear dark mahogany with a fizzy/frothy off-white head.  Sweet aroma of roasted caramel, dark fruits, cherries, some brandy notes.  Flavor follows and is slightly sweet with strong flavors of cherries and strawberries, toasted almonds and caramel, a bit of molasses, leading to a semi-dry complex finish.  An excellent interpretation of a brown ale, and one that I would have again and treat as a barley wine.
beer_name: Tyranena BGW High-Class Broad Imperial Brown Ale

review_blob: 2006 vintage, gushed all over my kitchen countertop.  Poured a cloudy effervescent deep gold with a small fizzy/frothy white head.  Aroma of citrus rind, barnhouse funk, a dash of tannic red wine, some light piney hops.  Flavor is slightly acidic and dry with notes of light toffee, some dry red wine, a bit of brett barn funk, with a tad bit of sweetness lingering in the back.  Very good, with complexity that surpasses the wine that once aged in the same barrels as this beer.  However, had it been more of a typical bold Belgian and not so much a wine/beer hybrid, I probably would have enjoyed it even more.  I continue to lament the idea that a beer needs to adapt wine notes in order to be considered sophisticated.

Bottle shared with my by my friend Jeff.  Poured dark brown with ruby highlights and a creamy/frothy light tan head.  A little light in color for an imperial stout.  Aroma is heavily laden with syrupy vanilla and caramelized sugar with just the slightest touch of roasted chocolate.  Flavor is quite sweet for an imperial stout, with lots of syrupy vanilla, butterscotch, caramel, chocolate, and a bit of dark fruit to round it all out.  Finishes surprisingly clean for an imperial.  I can see purists not liking this, as it is very sweet without a lot of the roasted character prevalent in more traditional examples of the style.  However, as a dessert beer this is an authentic attempt to recreate the flavors it advertises on its label, and overall Id say a success.
beer_name: Southern Tier Blackwater Series: Creme Brulee Stout

review_blob: Poured a murky mahogany brown with fizzy/frothy off-white head.  Spicy aroma of cinnamon, dark fruits, caramel.  Taste is of predominantly honey wheat bread, some cinnamon spiciness, a touch of fruit to it as well, finishing a slight bit of dryness.  The alcohol here is barely perceptible, an amazing feat at 13%.  Though not clubbing me with spiciness and not the deepest beer Ive had for its size, still a good drink that should in all fairness be a regular offering in some shape or form.

Poured a clear mohogany with a fizzy tall off-white head.  Aroma of sweet fruit, lots of charred wood, some roastiness.  Taste is very smoky with lots of charred wood (almost bacon-like), with some notes of sweet fruit and some dry alcohol peeking through on occasion.  Lots of carbonation gives a surprisingly lively feel to the body.  Im not an immediate fan of smoked beer, which was my primary reservation with this one.  Well made I suppose, which is why I still gave it a decent score even though its my preference of flavor profile.

beer_brewer_name: Schneider Weisse G. Schneider & Sohn GmbH
review_blob: Poured a very cloudy orangeish amber with a tall fluffy white head.  Sweet aroma of banana and clove, estery, with some notes of piney hops.  Flavor is a balance between sweet and dry with flavors of the banana and clove coming through, backed up by pine and grapefruit rind hops.  Overall much more estery than the Brooklyn counterpart with less hops emphasis and more balance.  In the end, this one does indeed have more of a German taste to it, while Brooklyns tasted more like an American take on a German style.  I probably enjoyed the American version more, but both are fantastic beers.

Poured a rich dark brown/black with a creamy light brown head.  Rich aroma of pipe tobacco, chocolate, strawberries, a bit of oak, roastiness.  Flavor isnt quite as impressive and comes off more one-dimensional, with notes of some dark fruits and burnt wood, a dash of chocolate, and a metallic alcoholic finish.  This beers nice aroma and beautiful appearance compels me to give it a decent score.  However, overall I consider it at best average for motivating my desire to return to it again in the future.  An ok experiment--and I will always give DFH credit for experimenting--but not as good as some of their year-round brews.

Poured an effervescent golden with a tall frothy white head.  Aroma of sweet orange and grapefruit, a bit of pine earthiness. Flavor is slightly sweet, lots of bitter grapefruit rind, pine needles, and earthiness, with a touch of a metallic character in the finish.  Body feels okay but somewhat thin.  Somewhat sweeter and cleaner, with sharper hops, and this would have been even better.

This was a gift from beeryum some time ago, opened at the faculty Oktoberfest.  Poured a rich mahogany with a tall creamy off-white head which refused to dissipate.  Rich aroma hits of smoke, raisins, pipe tobacco, biscuit dough and caramel toffee, alluring and inviting.  Flavor is a mix of sweet and dry, with notes of raisins, molasses and caramel, a touch of toffee.  Terrific, terrific beer, reminding me why this is my favorite German style.  As the bottle emptied to the sound of the overwhelming praise of my fellow faculty members, I could not help but curse my inability to get more of this brew.

Poured a very dark brown with a small off-white head.  Aroma of cinnamon and dark fruits, a bit of caramel and toffee.  Flavor is surprisingly spicy with notes of licorice dominating over dark fruits, leading to a somewhat spicy toffee-ish finish.  Complex and good, and though not what I was expecting from a strong Belgian, has some merits in its own right.  Id still prefer something a tad more traditional, though.
